---
title: "15 Of The Best Decision-Making Mental Models I've Found"
date: 2025-07-02
draft: false
---

<h1 id="">15 Of The Best Decision-Making Mental Models I've Found</h1><h2 id="">1) The Inside-Outside View</h2><p id="">We have a natural tendency to favour the inside view—our own independent solution to a problem that incorporates all of our hidden biases.</p><p id="">To make better decisions, we should favour the outside view—one that incorporates the best available data.</p><figure id="" class="w-richtext-figure-type-image w-richtext-align-center" data-rt-type="image" data-rt-align="center"><div id=""><img src="https://uploads-ssl.webflow.com/63fd511e232de229bfe66c52/640fabb4817e749fd7d9b716_FSKzmT0X0AAeLbl.jpeg" id="" width="auto" height="auto" loading="auto"></div></figure><h2 id="">2) Ladder of Inference</h2><p id="">Describes the thinking process we go through—often subconsciously—to get from a fact to a decision or action.</p><p id="">To make better decisions, we should move slowly and deliberately from the bottom of the ladder to the top of the ladder.</p><p id="">h/t (image) - <a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..TBHQLjVyEHTxPQRFoMYG_ZPHEpRp8X2Bci9Rnf1Vv5k" target="_blank" id="">@amrancz</a></p><figure id="" class="w-richtext-figure-type-image w-richtext-align-center" data-rt-type="image" data-rt-align="center"><div id=""><img src="https://uploads-ssl.webflow.com/63fd511e232de229bfe66c52/640fabb4cfbab517809c50ce_FSKzm91WYAAWjbb.jpeg" id="" width="auto" height="auto" loading="auto"></div></figure><h2 id="">3) Confidence Determines Speed vs. Quality</h2><p id="">The more confidence you have in the importance of a problem and your understanding of its solution, the more you should focus on quality.</p><p id="">However, if you need to learn more, move fast and break things.</p><p id="">h/t - <a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..Cgu3Nf8V8Fj4h8wz8P2qJ5SC-0HonmV1VL9uDtJsl4w" target="_blank" id="">@BrandonMChu</a></p><figure id="" class="w-richtext-figure-type-image w-richtext-align-center" data-rt-type="image" data-rt-align="center"><div id=""><img src="https://uploads-ssl.webflow.com/63fd511e232de229bfe66c52/640fabb4f883d08535635e13_FSKznfaXIAE24g0.jpeg" id="" width="auto" height="auto" loading="auto"></div></figure><h2 id="">4) Devil’s Advocate Position</h2><p id="">The antidote to confirmation bias.</p><p id="">It involves forcing yourself to view a decision from the opposite viewpoint or finding people who disagree with you.</p><p id="">It forces you to create a more compelling argument.</p><p id="">Don't take my word for it:</p><p id=""><em id="">"I never allow myself to have an opinion on anything that I don't know that other side's argument better than they do."</em></p><p id="">Charlie Munger</p><h2 id="">5) Pre-Mortem</h2><p id="">Pre-Mortem</p><p id="">Involves assuming that your decision has failed and working backwards to determine what the potential causes were.</p><p id="">This process has multiple benefits:</p><ul id=""><li id="">Removes overconfidence and irrational optimism</li><li id="">Reveals blind spots</li><li id="">Simplifies thinking</li></ul><p id="">h/t <a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..kX04n3JYruTbgk3qC-r_ji2AOPT17vbe_kv5X24gJSs" target="_blank" id="">@KleInsight</a></p><figure id="" class="w-richtext-figure-type-image w-richtext-align-center" data-rt-type="image" data-rt-align="center"><div id=""><img src="https://uploads-ssl.webflow.com/63fd511e232de229bfe66c52/640fabb46084e32903408daa_FSKzo2WWUAEenet.jpeg" id="" width="auto" height="auto" loading="auto"></div></figure><h2 id="">6) Post-Mortem</h2><p id="">Regardless of success or failure, this can be used to drive continuous improvement in your decision-making.</p><p id="">Here, you ask:</p><ul id=""><li id="">What went well?</li><li id="">What went poorly?</li><li id="">What can be improved next time?</li></ul><p id="">With the answers, future decisions will be better informed.</p><h2 id="">7) Decision Trees</h2><p id="">These are tree-like graphs with the branches showing results of possible choices for a given decision or action.</p><p id="">The decision tree allows options to be compared against each other, for both risk and return.</p><p id="">They're particularly helpful for financial decisions.</p><figure id="" class="w-richtext-figure-type-image w-richtext-align-center" data-rt-type="image" data-rt-align="center"><div id=""><img src="https://uploads-ssl.webflow.com/63fd511e232de229bfe66c52/640fabb45ee0d9ffbb5a3c5d_FSKzpbcWQAk-Ccb.jpeg" id="" width="auto" height="auto" loading="auto"></div></figure><h2 id="">8) Information Overload</h2><p id="">Information overload is when you have too much information at hand.</p><p id="">This causes decisions to take too long.</p><p id="">It also leads to 'analysis paralysis' where your decision-making suffers paralysis because you over-analyze the body of information available.</p><h2 id="">9) Analysis Paralysis</h2><p id="">It's the paradox of choice: having too many good options slows us down because the best one isn't clear.</p><p id="">Remember: by not making a choice, you are actually making a choice: the status quo.</p><p id="">A model to cope with this: reversible vs. irreversible decisions.</p><h2 id="">10) Reversible vs. Irreversible Decisions</h2><p id="">Irreversible decisions are 'one-way doors.'</p><p id="">They must be made slowly and deliberately.</p><p id="">Reversible decisions are 'two-way doors.'</p><p id="">These decisions can and should be made quickly.</p><figure id="" class="w-richtext-figure-type-video w-richtext-align-center" style="padding-bottom:33.75%" data-rt-type="video" data-rt-align="center" data-rt-max-width="" data-rt-max-height="33.75%" data-rt-dimensions="0:0" data-page-url=""><div id=""><iframe scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true" src="https://platform.twitter.com/embed/Tweet.html?dnt=false&embedId=twitter-widget-0&%3D&frame=false&hideCard=false&hideThread=false&id=1521889962454626308&lang=en&origin=https%3A%2F%2Falexbrogan.beehiiv.com%2Fp%2F15-mental-models-to-enhance-your-decision-making&sessionId=0e085c928bdde7d16492d6b3d3cfa0b1c6121bbe&theme=light&widgetsVersion=aaf4084522e3a%3A1674595607486&width=550px"></iframe></div></figure><h2 id="">11) Luck Razor</h2><p id="">If stuck with 2 equal options, pick the one that feels like it will produce the most luck later down the line.</p><p id="">Should I stay in tonight or should I go and meet this interesting stranger?</p><p id="">Choose to increase your surface area of luck when you have the choice.</p><h2 id="">12) Make Proud Decisions for Your 80-Year Old and 10-Year Old Self</h2><p id="">Your 80-year-old self helps you makes decisions you won't regret when you're old.</p><p id="">Your 10-year-old self reminds you to stay foolish and have some fun along the way.</p><p id="">h/t - <a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..PP9-skVmVdddh495DKuAbkqtUalyflnfz9NB9MhSjMM" target="_blank" id="">@SahilBloom</a></p><h2 id="">13) Minimize Unforced Errors </h2><p id="">A concept from tennis, 'unforced error' is a metaphor for any situation where an avoidable mistake is made.</p><p id="">The first goal of decision-making should always be to minimize unforced errors.</p><p id="">How?</p><p id="">Sound judgement and decision making techniques.</p><h2 id="">14) Outcome Blind</h2><p id="">The biggest mistake when judging performance is only looking at the outcome.</p><p id="">Instead, we should focus on the process used.</p><p id="">It's possible to win with a bad decision making process (luck) or lose with a good process.</p><p id="">What's important is knowing the 'Why.'</p><h2 id="">15) 10/10/10 Rule</h2><p id="">We're all guilty of making decisions without thinking about long term consequences.</p><p id="">To avoid this, ask:</p><ul id=""><li id="">How will I feel about this 10 minutes from now?</li><li id="">10 months from now?</li><li id="">10 years from now?</li></ul><p id="">This helps clarify the decision that results in a win/win/win.</p>
